Positive: It's incredible to see groundbreaking advancements in the fight against brain cancer. Richard Scolyer's dedication and innovation are truly inspiring. This new treatment offers hope to so many battling this devastating disease, and it's heartening to see its success recognized on such a significant platform. Here's to continued progress in the field of medical research and to the countless lives that will be impacted by this breakthrough.

Yup!
> Now, work is underway developing protocols for the start of clinical trials. If the results of those trials are strong, it could shake-up the current treatment regimen of surgery, chemotherapy and radiation that has not changed in 19 years.

We've know this for a long time.  Once you learn to use a hammer everything looks like a nail.  Good for him.

This is amazing news and three cheers to Professor Scolyer and Professor Long for their contributions.   Professor Scolyer is the ultimate in practicing leading from the front.  As someone who had a good friend pass away of glioblastoma in the past year, this is one of those cancers that is largely an unavoidable death sentence at the moment.  That sounds like it's changing.
Neutral: Lost my sister at 34 to a brain tumor/cancer (she chose not to have it biopsied because the location meant that it was terminal either way.). Props to this guy for working to ensure that fewer families have to go through what we did.

Positive: Is this political? This just seems like another normal thing

I went to college in Wisconsin and my one Professor was Hmong.  He told us their history and situation in the U.S. in relation to the Vietnam War and how the communities live in Wisconsin. It was something that many people don't know about in terms of war refugees and how they were basically scattered across the country far from each other. That communities like the one in Wisconsin came about due to Hmong people trying to reach out and connect with each other decades after being relocated. I am happy that this happened and that it can help inform people more about the situation of refugees and their difficulties in relocation and adjusting. I am sure my Professor is happy about this news.
I wonder if they'll teach the real history, or sanitized revisionism.
